lessonOverview.title: Unit 7 - Lesson 5
phonics: soft c - ce ci cy, soft g - ge gig y

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “soft c” and “soft g” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Write “circle, giraffe, juice” on the board. Students say and sort into “soft c” or “soft g” sound columns. Drill with actions.
stretchStrategies: Lost Property Poster – Groups design a “Lost and Found” poster for the school. Include objects, numbers (e.g., “3 keys, 2 rings”), and short sentences. Share with class and ask comprehension Qs. Links reading + real world learning.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about mixing colours and painting a picture and find key details such as colour combinations.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read together, then ask: “What colours did they mix?” Students highlight colours and draw the mixed result.
stretchStrategies: Lost Property Poster – Groups design a “Lost and Found” poster for the school. Include objects, numbers (e.g., “3 keys, 2 rings”), and short sentences. Share with class and ask comprehension Qs. Links reading + real world learning.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn what colours you can make by mixing different primary colours together.
supportStrategies: (Art) Do a mini colour-mixing demo with crayons or on the board. Ask: “What colour do we make?” Link to vocabulary from the reading.

items: A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
